Percy Praises Today's Youth;
Cites Growth of'Republicanism'
Senator Charles Percy, speaking Monday night at Shriver Hall,
characterized America as a "fretful and moody" nation, uncomfortable with its prosperity and
uncertain about its might.
He praised the young people of
this country for posing serious
questions about society and for
rising to its challenges. He cited
the present college generation's
rejection of material .abundance
as a criteria for greatness. He
commended the constructive action in organizations such as the
Peace Corps, VISTA, and tutorials.
GOP "Constructive"
Senator Percy felt the Republican Party is also involved in
"constructiveness." He said his
party was becoming the party of
"proposition as well as of opposition." He praised such Republican officials as Senator Hatfield,
Governors Romney, Rockefeller,
and Agnew, and Mayor Lindsay,
for being responsive to the needs
of the people and progressive in

their solutions and their actions.
The Senator said that in an era
of big business, big unions and
big government, the issue for the
states and the Republicans was
not States Rights but State Responsibility. He said that if states
acted aggressively to solve their
own problems there would be no
need for massive Federal intervention. To facilitate this, he endorsed the idea of Tax Sharing,
whereby each state would get a
certain percentage of Federal
taxes to be disposed as it sees
Et to solve its own problems.
Democratize the Cities
Senator Percy described his
Home Ownership Bill as the way
to "democratize the cities." He
has proposed that the government renovate tenements and sell
them to the poor while subsidizing the payments if necessary.
This, he said, would give the poor
a sense of ownership and a pride
in their home. In this way they
would realize the responsibilities
of ownership and care for pri-

vate property.
When questioned on Latin
American Foreign Policy, Senator
Percy said that we had unfortunately supported some dictators who desired to preserve the
status quo against the will of the
people. He stated that we should
he selective and support only
those governments which are
genuinely concerned for their
people and will progressively help
themselves. By doing this, Percy
felt the U.S. could avoid future
Vietnams."We cannot and should
not be the policeman of the
world," said the Senator.
Senator Percy said he hoped to
see the draft become as voluntary as possible. He said he
would like to see a draftee have
the option of serving at age 19
or of delaying his service four
years for educational purposes.
Nevertheless, he would be forced
to serve at some time. He recommended that more jobs in the
armed forces be opened to
women.

Shame On Barton
The word "shame" was etched into the brick facade
Hall this past week. We deplore this action of
Barton
of
vandalism because it is a malicious destruction of private property and because it is an ineffective avenue for
argument. But we also sympathize with the frustration
and anger that apparently prompted the act.
Although directed to the wrong quarters, it is obvious that some students are sickened at the thought
that Hopkins is carrying on germ and chemical warfare
research for the Government. Or perhaps the action was
aimed against the secrecy that surrounds both the Barton
Hall physics research and the Medical Institutions bacterological warfare research. In either case an unhealthy
attitude has been bred which leads to acts of vandalism,
such as the "shame", by disturbed students.
In attacking the present Hopkins policy of accepting
classified Army contracts on germ and chemical warfare, we wish to clarify the point that it is not a moral
question. Issues can not be decided on the high plains of
morality to anyone's satisfaction. We view the problem
pragmatically. There is a contradiction involved when a
free, private university takes on secret Army research
contracts in biological warfare research. So far we have
received unsatisfactory answers to the questions of
whether Hopkins can find something more constructive
to do, and whether secret research is beneficial to the
academic community or to the public.
The plans for a disruption of the game Saturday
to protest secret germ and chemical warfare research
at Hopkins will undoubtedly bring attention to the problem. We feel that the protest would be justified as a
gesture to the administration that their backhand whitewash of the entire episode did not satisfy the concerned
students of Hopkins.
We use the modifier "concerned" to distinguish between tile handful of campus activists and establishment
BMOCs, and the great gray mass of prematurely middleaged students at Hopkins. This unresponsive mass of
primeaval jelly is not going to be exhorted to rise up
against germ and chemical warfare research, for they
may be of a different opinion on the subject. Instead we
exhort the great gray mass to at least respond in some
way to the issues that swirl around them. The selfish
apathy they practice can only bring them contempt and
lead them to the attitude of "not getting involved."
This publication has constantly striven to elicit
reaction from its readers, either pro or con. We often
judge the worth of any article by the number of angry
letters we receive. We have worked to create an atmosphere of passive anarchy, where voices from all sides
can bring about an understanding on any given issue.
Apathy is not ignorance of Student Council elections, but
rather the disregard of issues of a wider scope.
Why care? Because if one limits his interests only
to getting a degree, the final product will be defective.
Losing touch with the world and with other people
creates only a generation of hollow men. What is needed
here is a little existential virtue to drive the living dead
of Hopkins into some sort of commitment that will enrich both themselves and the community.
Tired of committee action and concensus decisions,
this activist group that is disturbed by germ and chemical warfare is taking a direct approach to the problem.
In this we commend the group of faculty, graduates,
and undergraduates in their protest.
The subject of secret bacteriological research at
Hopkins should bring a rise out of everybody, because it
ultimately concerns everyone. The Department of Pathology at the Medical Institutions has taken a contract to do
research on a peculiar weapons system for the Army.
Isn't there something else that could be done at those
labs? Why keep the research secret at an educational
institutional which searches for the "truth"? Does Hopkins have to place its integrity on the line by accepting
$80,000,000 in Government contracts, or can the money
be elicited from one of the private research underwriters? These are questions which the administration
has failed to answer, anti which most students have failed
to ask.
We urge the administration to take notice of the
feeling of anxiety among students concerning secret
germ and chemical warfare,research and to take positive
measures in remoigng the shrouded figure of secrecy
from Hopkins.

By ELIA KATZ
What's this? SHAME? Does
someone in the corpulent intellectual organism that is Hopkins
feel SHAME about something?
About what? Can't think of a
thing, and yet somebody has
written SHAME in big painted
letters on Barton Hall. (As I am
writing about it, there are eleven
men in coveralls scraping the
SHAME off—it being 10:00 now
and they having started at 7:00).
Maybe someone wants to get a
message to us about the place.
Can't tell.
But if he is, he is not so very
yvrong. Because Barton Hall, no
matter what they do there, or
for what purpose, is the appropriate brick symbol on campus for
the placement of contradictory
paint symbols. The building being silence and the SHAME (0!
the uncouthness of writing on a
wall—better you should have
tiied to talk to it, vandal!) being
a scream. So that would be a
good place to go to put a message
on a wall, if that's what you
wanted to do. And he did.
SHAME?
What in God's name is he
aSHAMEd about? We don't know.
Can't be certain. Can only surmise. Don't even really give a
damn. We can only use that word
(Right about now the men in
coveralls have succeeded in cut-

SHAME. What we—the rest of
us—have to be aSHAMEd about
is not at all ambiguous.
It comes down to this:
That there is secret research
(the nature of this research may
be objectionable to some and
admirable to others—no matter)
on our campus. That the Johns
Hopkins University should be, as
are all great places of teaching
and learning, committed to the
dissemination, not the subversion, of knowledge. Knowledge
and opinions are the only things
we're here for. They are what
make Hopkins a University as
opposed to a subterranian military installation. All of which
means that whatever goes on at
Hopkins is public, buddy. It is
community property. And anything they do here that they keep
secret they ought to stop doing.
Take it away. It is a perversion
of academia. Take it to a basement in Jersey and work on it
there, because what we do here
we've got to show-and-tell about.
I mean we are famous as the
place where all the professors
have to publish like a sonofagun.

Singleton's Dante Studies are not
secret. Nor is Morrill's Calculus.
The SHAME is that Hopkins
could be allowing classified research to go on under our good
name and with our auspices,
when this is not the place for
such goings-on. The nature of
the research is not known (vague
accusations that they make bugs
are met by vaguenesses that drift
down to us and say the bugs are
"defensive," etc. Meaningless) but
the nature of the research is not
even at issue. Only that it is
secret. And it is here. And there
shouldn't be any secrets here.
That's all.
That's a SHAME on us,
a terrible SHAME (precisely)
SHAME.
Petition
The following is a petition currently being circulated around
the campus:
"The undersigned members of
the Johns Hopkins community
are completely opposed to the
conduct of secret military research at Hopkins. Quite apart
from the nature of the research,
secret research as such is totally
incompatible with the traditions
and values of science and scholarship of a great university. This
university — our university —
should not engage in such research."

Senator Charles Percy, speaking Monday night at Shriver Hall,
characterized America as a "fretful and moody" nation, uncomfortable with its prosperity and
uncertain about its might.
He praised the young people of
this country for posing serious
questions about society and for
rising to its challenges. He cited
the present college generation's
rejection of material .abundance
as a criteria for greatness. He
commended the constructive action in organizations such as the
Peace Corps, VISTA, and tutorials.

"constructiveness." He said his
party was becoming the party of
"proposition as well as of opposition." He praised such Republican officials as Senator Hatfield,
Governors Romney, Rockefeller,
and Agnew, and Mayor Lindsay,
for being responsive to the needs
of the people and progressive in

their solutions and their actions.

of big business, big unions and
big government, the issue for the
states and the Republicans was
not States Rights but State Responsibility. He said that if states
acted aggressively to solve their
own problems there would be no
need for massive Federal intervention. To facilitate this, he endorsed the idea of Tax Sharing,
whereby each state would get a
certain percentage of Federal
taxes to be disposed as it sees
Et to solve its own problems.

Home Ownership Bill as the way
to "democratize the cities." He
has proposed that the government renovate tenements and sell
them to the poor while subsidizing the payments if necessary.
This, he said, would give the poor
a sense of ownership and a pride
in their home. In this way they
would realize the responsibilities
of ownership and care for pri-

vate property.

Shame On Barton
The word "shame" was etched into the brick facade
Hall this past week. We deplore this action of
Barton
of
vandalism because it is a malicious destruction of private property and because it is an ineffective avenue for
argument. But we also sympathize with the frustration
and anger that apparently prompted the act.
Although directed to the wrong quarters, it is obvious that some students are sickened at the thought
that Hopkins is carrying on germ and chemical warfare
research for the Government. Or perhaps the action was
aimed against the secrecy that surrounds both the Barton
Hall physics research and the Medical Institutions bacterological warfare research. In either case an unhealthy
attitude has been bred which leads to acts of vandalism,
such as the "shame", by disturbed students.
In attacking the present Hopkins policy of accepting
classified Army contracts on germ and chemical warfare, we wish to clarify the point that it is not a moral
question. Issues can not be decided on the high plains of
morality to anyone's satisfaction. We view the problem
pragmatically. There is a contradiction involved when a
free, private university takes on secret Army research
contracts in biological warfare research. So far we have
received unsatisfactory answers to the questions of
whether Hopkins can find something more constructive
to do, and whether secret research is beneficial to the
academic community or to the public.
The plans for a disruption of the game Saturday
to protest secret germ and chemical warfare research
at Hopkins will undoubtedly bring attention to the problem. We feel that the protest would be justified as a
gesture to the administration that their backhand whitewash of the entire episode did not satisfy the concerned
students of Hopkins.
We use the modifier "concerned" to distinguish between tile handful of campus activists and establishment
BMOCs, and the great gray mass of prematurely middleaged students at Hopkins. This unresponsive mass of
primeaval jelly is not going to be exhorted to rise up
against germ and chemical warfare research, for they
may be of a different opinion on the subject. Instead we
exhort the great gray mass to at least respond in some
way to the issues that swirl around them. The selfish
apathy they practice can only bring them contempt and
lead them to the attitude of "not getting involved."
This publication has constantly striven to elicit
reaction from its readers, either pro or con. We often
judge the worth of any article by the number of angry
letters we receive. We have worked to create an atmosphere of passive anarchy, where voices from all sides
can bring about an understanding on any given issue.
Apathy is not ignorance of Student Council elections, but
rather the disregard of issues of a wider scope.
